answers.content: Programming goal is to reuse components in a smart way. What you're doing is on the right path since there’s no conflict. Using the constructor for Question and Answer while having separate create and delete methods for QuestionList and AnswerList makes sense, as it keeps object creation simple while allowing better management of collections. That said, there are multiple ways to implement this and your approach might be one of them.

That is a crticial first step. It may be possible to do all of the work in the constructor in some cases. In some other, you may have to create two things which refer to one another. content: What does it mean by "positive and negative outcomes" in the tasks 2 and 3? For test cases does it mean failure of the test? What do you mean by cover that? If it fails shouldn't we just fix our code, or should we write about that process. What is a negative or positive user story? Task 2: A subset of the Student User Stories. (15%) User Stories cover CRUD operations on the question and the answer classes. (5%) User Stories cover CRUD operations on lists of questions and answers. (5%) User Stores cover both positive and negative outcomes. (5%) Task 3: A list of Test Cases. (15%) Testing on CRUD operations on the question and the answer classes using realistic data. (5%) Testing on CRUD operations on lists of questions and answers. (5%) Testing covers both positive and negative outcomes. (5%)

answers.content: Positive and negative outcomes in Tasks 2 and 3 refer to testing both successful scenarios (positive) and failure scenarios (negative). In Task 2, a positive user story describes a successful action, such as "As a student, I can edit my question to correct mistakes." A negative user story focuses on preventing invalid actions, like "As a student, I should see an error if I try to submit a blank question." In Task 3, a positive test case confirms that the system works correctly, such as a student successfully posting a question. A negative test case checks how the system handles errors, like trying to post a question with an empty input triggering an error message. If a test fails, you should fix your code and document the failure to show how the system detects and responds to errors.

content: I know this class says it doesn't require us to use sql but that isn't exactly true. I have zero experience with databases. Does anyone have a good resource to get me caught up on the subject?

answers.content: There will be a lecture about SQL on the 12th week. In the mean time, you can refer to other reliable sources to learn more about SQL, coursera for example (https://www.coursera.org/search?query=sql)

You can implement this project without a database. Java can write out complex objects to a file just before ending execution and then read in the objects during start-up the next time the program is used. This is the sort of discussion you should be having with your team, as the impact is. on the team, not just you as an individual.

Check out the Tutorials and Docs for SQL on W3Schools! I always find them really helpful. You don't need to go in depth. It's best to read through DatabaseHelper.java and try to understand what is happening. Once you do, it's easy to replicate and repurpose those methods into the new ones you need. Also, it really helps to think about SQL databases as an excel spreadsheet, where your columns are the attributes your class has (User has an id, name, email, password) and the rows are your entries. Those would make up your table. SQL is very specific - it doesn't like Strings where Ints are supposed to be for example! You can't insert a new entry that has only 2 columns (aka attributes) into a table that has 4 columns (aka attributes). SQL also lets you search and filter your entries in a given table! :0) Definitely read up on it because you will need it later, and it's super useful in the industry. Don't try to become an expert though (at least not yet), get the knowledge you need and keep on goin'!
You are not required to use DB for your project and homework. We have modules and lectures on this.

content: HW 2 outlines Class 3 and Class 4 as follows: a questions class that supports storing all current questions as well as any subset of the questions (e.g., a subset reflecting the results of a search) an answers class that supports storing all potential answers to all stored questions and any subset of potential answers to a question (e.g., a subset reflecting the results of a search) Could someone clarify what the bolded/italics parts mean? Is this referring to a subset of any form of response (either question or answer is allowed) to the each currently-posted question (for class 3) or each currently-posted answer (for class 4)?

answers.content: When you search for a question, your program should filter and display only those questions that match the search keywords, creating a subset of all available questions. The same logic applies to the answers class. When searching for answers, only the relevant answers to the filtered questions should be shown. This way, both classes support storing the full set of questions and answers, as well as dynamic subsets based on search results. Hope that helps clarify things!

content: Hi all, Here is my understanding of HW2 from the Individual Homework 2 document on Canvas. We are supposed to create a standalone program that can do CRUD operations and input validation for a question and answer system. You may implement this from Foundation Code, HW1, or your TP1 code. You pick a subset of user stories from "Student" that you think best cover what is required for CRUD/input validation - it's vague because it is up to your best judgement. CRUD stands for Create, Read, Update, Delete. Input validation is how you make sure your database is secure when allowing users to enter things directly into your database. If you're taking 365, think SQL injection and all the things that can go wrong there. Note that it is standalone. I don't think this means it isn't related to HW1 or our team projects -- Instead, I think it means it is a more simple adaptation, requiring only enough to get these basic functionalities in place and not worry about roles and their effect on what a user can do. It is to practice on a smaller scale and get a working idea of what we will implement, before we actually implement it into the team project. You should think like this too! It's just a mini version of the Q&A system we are developing. In the document it says to create: a question class an answer class a questions class that supports storing all current questions as well as any subset of the questions (e.g., a subset reflecting the results of a search) an answers class that supports storing all potential answers to all stored questions and any subset of potential answers to a question (e.g., a subset reflecting the results of a search) Lets look a little deeper here. The question class represents a single question and all of the data associated with it (Think: how are questions displayed on EdDiscussion? What information do they have?) Same with the answer class, but for answers to questions. Think about that relationship. What about the last two? (TAs please correct me if I'm wrong) I think these are to manage a collection of questions/answers, maybe like a category of questions (on EdDiscussion, "Assignments" questions vs "Exams" questions) or answers related to a question (q: "What is the meaning of life?", answers: "42", "Playing with my dog", "Making an impact" (where the question and answer classes are just simple strings). What might that data look like? How might we interact with it? Remember we can have multiple collections, collections that are empty, have a few entries, or that 1000s of entries. Do some research on collections of data like this, it'll help a lot down the line. We are urged to discuss "potential attributes" for these classes with each other on EdDiscussion. Again, this is vague because it is up to you! Talk to others about these and learn from others' previous experiences. Documentation and automated testing is still important. Use JavaDoc comments for documentation, they're pretty cool. Automated testing is like in TP1 still. No need to worry about JUnit, if you don't want to. Read the deliverables and note theres a lot planning, documentation, diagrams, and testing in the deliverable PDF. And finally a screencast to explain and show off your work. K. I. S. S. (Keep it simple silly) method for the screencast, so you don't bore your grader :P I think I got everything! So, to recap: Create a standalone, mini question and answer system based off of a subset of the student user stories that best cover CRUD operations and input validation. It can be started from Foundation Code, HW1, or TP1. Make your own separate Github repository for this homework. Don't fork - If you fork, it will make the repository public and we don't want that! Better to download as a zip, open it, and initialize a new repository from it. You need to code 4 new classes and write database operations for them (CRUD). Their inputs should be validated to prevent saving bad data into our DB. If you're Staff and notice something is wrong with my interpretation, please let me know!

content: Hi! If we got any code from a specific course or AI tool like Chat GPT, how would you like us to cite the source we used?

answers.content: In the syllabus it says "Generative AI is a technology that can often be useful in helping students learn the theories and concepts in this course. However, unless explicitly allowed by your instructor, the use of generative AI tools to complete any portion of a course assignment or exam will be considered academic dishonesty and a violation of the ASU Academic Integrity Policy. Students confirmed to be engaging in non-allowable use of generative AI will be sanctioned according to the academic integrity policy and FSE sanctioning guidelines." Also, it says "All submissions may be checked for plagiarism and improper AI usage." So you can use AI by using it to write code seems to be the "improper AI usage" as you are not using it as a learning material. Moreover, ChatGPT is not really a source as it takes information from multiple sources. I would use the any search engine preferably google.

Hello. You are not allowed to use code generated by AI tools or shared by others on the internet. However, you may use such resources to gather ideas for potential solutions before writing your own code. If you reference any AI-generated code or code obtained from external sources, you must explicitly acknowledge it in your code or report. For example: "To implement this part of the code, I received help from [AI tool/Web address]." Please note that making minor modifications to AI-generated code or borrowed code, like changing the style or names, does not eliminate plagiarism.

content: For Task 2 in Admin: "I can set a one-time password for a user who has forgotten their password so they can establish a new password. Once a user has logged in with the one-time password, it is cleared so it can’t be used again. After establishing a new password, the user is required to log in again." Can I create a new reset password page file that redirects the user to the reset password page?

answers.content: in data base helper java file you can uncomment the second to last line of the try block to reset your whole data base. public void connectToDatabase() throws SQLException { try { Class.forName(JDBC_DRIVER); // Load the JDBC driver System.out.println("Connecting to database..."); connection = DriverManager.getConnection(DB_URL, USER, PASS); statement = connection.createStatement(); // You can use this command to clear the database and restart from fresh. //statement.execute("DROP ALL OBJECTS"); createTables(); // Create the necessary tables if they don't exist } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) { System.err.println("JDBC Driver not found: " + e.getMessage()); } }

It is up to you if you want to redirect the user to a new page to reset his password. Through your research of other sites, you should examine how other sites handle this issue. Moreover, as a user, it doesn't really harm you to do the forgot password process on the same page, but it is not the norm, which might confuse some users, yet it is still up to you and your team.

content: Are the requirements for input validation HW 1 sufficient for Team Project Phase 1? Or are there other requirements outside of what we've done that aren't mentioned in the user stories or HW1.

answers.content: It's up to you and your team to work together and fill in any gaps that are missing. Follow the user stories carefully, read the requirements, assess your result and repeat.

The lack of input validation is one of the ways that bad people break into systems, steal information and money, and cause harm. Look at Team Project Phase 1 assignment and search for the word "validation". What do you think the answer to your question should be?

content: So for new users, should they randomly get a role, or after they register, should an admin assign them the role?

answers.content: The user should have at least one role in the system. As a new user, the first or only user must be an admin. An admin is responsible for assigning one or more roles among other responsibilities. If the user is randomly assigned a role which they shouldn’t have access to, then that might not be a good idea. What if that 2nd random gets admin privileges, they could wrongfully delete your non-admin users.

How do you think the Bank of America website works or that of any important organization? Are roles randomly assigned? View the User Stories, search for the word "role", and ask yourself "Who can set and modify a role?"

You can practice this with your homework assignments and reach out to your team in case someone knows more or you can all learn together. Look up standards and good practice when it comes to using it. Edit: Just a general idea, but help graders by keeping them separate.

metadata.title: TP Phase 1 - New Users, Admins all or some?

content: Hello all, Thank you for keeping up with the crazy amount of questions on here. Great work! I have a few of my own, but want to provide a bit of context. So pardon the long form! My team is aware we should complete user stories from New Users and Admin, including some new ones or at least better informed ones from our research on real-world applications/websites. During the live event, Dr. Carter stated that in real life it is not wise to simply add things to the user stories given to you by stakeholders. The reason was because if it ended up being a waste of time or adding cost, the team could end up paying for this. Is this something we are replicating in this course? Do I need to get confirmation about adding new things to my user stories from stakeholders (Professors, TAs, Graders)? If so, do I do this via EdDiscussion? Also during the live event, Dr. Carter stated we should complete 'some' user stories (from New Users and Admins), but didn't specify how much we are truly expected to do for Phase I. Based on the Phase I instructions and deliverables, it is clear we need to work with new inputs and validation for those new inputs (i.e. improve the sign flow for the 'first' user role and all New Users). However, are we also expected that we implement new roles (Student, Instructors, Reviewers, Staff) and the invitation code functionality that must come with it? Are we expected to implement the list of user accounts, adding and removing roles, deleting users functionalities for Admins? Are we expected to implement the 'Choose a Role' Page for users with multiple roles? Are we expected to show any information on the Role specific pages yet, not including Admin? Also, the online class is still missing the Template .docx for Phase I. Here is a bulleted list of my questions to make it easier to read: Do I need to get confirmation about adding new things to my user stories from stakeholders (Professors, TAs, Graders)? If so, do I do this via EdDiscussion? Are we expected to implement all features described in New Users and Admins epics? If not, which ones are we expected to complete for Phase I exactly? Are we expected that we implement new roles (Student, Instructors, Reviewers, Staff) and the invitation code functionality that must come with it? Are we expected to implement the list of user accounts, adding and removing roles, deleting users functionalities for Admins? Are we expected to implement the 'Choose a Role' Page for users with multiple roles? Are we expected to show any information on the Role specific pages yet, not including Admin? The online class is still missing the Template .docx for Phase I. Can this be provided today? Please give me definitive answers. I would like to create an environment of calm and complete understanding of tasks for my team. This would really help me accomplish this! Again, I truly appreciate your work answering the constant influx of questions on here! It's difficult to keep up with and has been helping me immensely. I hope I can give back to my classmates by asking these here. Thank you for your time and knowledge :o) If you have further questions for me, let me know! Thank you, Amelia - Online Team 3

answers.content: Hey Amelia, 1. You are expected to fill in the blanks for some of the new user stories that you might think is required. So for example, customer can be very vague about what they they want, so it's your task a software engineer to decipher their needs. In this class, the professors and us TAs would serve as customers, so it's always better to confirm with us through Live Sessions, Office Hours, Ed Discussions if the functionality you are thinking of adding is actually aligning with the customer requirements 2. You are to implement all the user stories of New User and Admin, however, for the functionalities/roles that are yet to be implemented, you can use placeholders for those things. For example, Admin can assign the user any roles during invitation (have that flexibility), What happens to a user with a specific role is not required at this phase, only confirm that the role is assigned. (Further clarifications in office hours as needed) 3. You are to implement the option to assign/select new roles (think of it as just a label at this point) 4. Yes, but it does not have to be through a persistent way (using database) at this phase 5. Yes, again assume merely assigning different label at this point 6. No 7. The template will be provided over the weekend (it will be similar to HW1 template) Thank you for understanding and keep asking questions if any other ambiguity arises.
I want to clarify. Professors will play the role of customers in this class. NOT the TAs, Graders, or UGTAs.

content: When we submit the team project, does each group member need to submit it individually, or is it sufficient to submit just one copy with all the team members’ names on it?

answers.content: Only one member has to submit, but it is everyone's responsibility to make sure the document/submission is accurate and completely submitted before the deadline

content: So for the standup meeting recordings, when we get together in person, are we supposed to record ourselves discussing the project? also same question for going virtual.

answers.content: The assignment discusses how these stand-up meetings are held. Here is the reference: "One key norm is meeting at least twice a week for a "stand-up" meeting, where each member of the team describes in just two to three minutes 1) what they accomplish, 2) what the plan to accomplish, 3) issues that are blocking progress. This meeting must be recorded and submitted with thew two other required screencasts described below in Task 7. (Consider using Zoom to do the recording.). The purpose of this communications meeting is to identify activities where collaboration may be required. Waiting until integration to discover that two or more team members made changes to the same set of classes (methods and attributes) without agreeing on what those changes need to be can be catastrophic! The meeting is not a problem solving meeting. (For more about this kind of meeting read this article, Daily Scrum MeetingLinks to an external site.."

content: Is there a limit to how many new features we can add? Or is there a minimum number we need to include?

answers.content: You need to satisfy the requirements (that' s your bare minimum). And as to a limit of new features, this is up to your team to engineer and what may come across later. Coming up with new/cool features helps your team stay motivated and encourages everyone to collaborate and therefore achieve a great product for your customer.

The only new stories you are expected to add are those that provide more detail about some story that has been provided. (E.g., Expanding an epic into reasonable-sized User Stories for actual implementation. There is no extra credit for doing more than what is required. As Fausto stated, if adding some new features excites your team and does not detract from the required functions, go for it!

content: Hi ! I’m a bit confused about Task 10. Is the mentioned PasswordRecognizer class actually referring to the PasswordEvaluator class, or do we need to create a new file specifically named PasswordRecognizer class? In the instructions for updating the FMS, it states: "Allow minus signs, underscores, and period characters between subsequent alphanumeric characters." Does this mean that multiple special characters (minus, period, underscore) are permitted in a row, or are they restricted to appearing only individually between alphanumeric characters? For instance, would examples like "John______doe" or "John_.-doe" be considered valid?

answers.content: I think neither of those are valid. The requirement is that those special characters are only allowed between subsequent alphanumeric chars, so the only valid sequence is [alphaNumeric] [specialChar] [alphaNumeric], and if that third character is anything but alphanumeric, that username would be invalid. The subsequent requirement also, I believe, prevents you from ending with a special character.

content: I had a few unnecessary issues going through this homework as an online student specifically and only in terms of the instructions provided for the assignment. Honestly, as a student who cares about my grade and gets very frustrated with assignments that are poorly created (as even one of the TAs ALSO told me in a zoom call), I wonder how much my grade will suffer going forwards in terms of losing points because I did assignments entirely incorrectly due to extremely vague instructions. content: For the implementation in Foundation code, do we implement the provided FSM under step 8 for both username and password? I have created only one FSM method that works for both username and password, along with another method that helps to identify if the input is for username or password. Also, are we allowed to use the static methods of the Character class to validate uppercase, lowercase, etc., or should we manually write them as it is written in the checkForValidUserName method?

answers.content: For step 8, yes, that approach should be correct. Implementing a method that works for both username and password should be valid as long as it satisfies the requirements of the FSM. *Note that you should have duplicated your Foundational Code application and named it HW1 instructed in step 6. Step 9 asks that you confirm that the code behaves as intended with both of the FSM's. So if it doesn't then I'd pivot towards revising your code. And I wouldn't be too sure about the static methods, try writing them in a consistent manner with the provided code/comments (be sure you can explain this in your HW1 documentation). Edit: if you're referring to using things like isUpperCase() or isLowerCase(), that should work.

The Foundation Code is just a framework. The way it processes usernames and passwords is inappropriate for a real application. The code that is there provides no input validation. It allows a single-character username and a single-character password. Rather than implementing these input validations from a blank piece of paper, why not reuse existing code (updating it if needed), and integrate the reused code into the Foundation Code? You have been asked to update the Foundation code by reusing the code from the provided FSM-based applications to check the input for a username and a password and rejecting those inputs if they do not satisfy the requirements. The Foundation Code GUI must be updated for these enhancements to be useful.

content: Hello! Does the FSM image for Task 4 have a discrepancy? It is somewhat confusing to me, so I want to make sure. I included the image in this thread. I highlighted the discrepancy with a red rectangle. Is the transition from state 1 to state 2 (the arrow from state 1 to state 2) supposed to be labeled with '. [2]' instead of '. [1]'? I confirmed with the source code for UserNameRecognizer and this appears to be a discrepancy that should get fixed if or at least announced to prevent students from getting confused by the image and how they read it.

answers.content: Hey Alex, since state 2 is not an accepted state, we really don't need to check for the length of the userName. Only if we see a valid userName i.e. the final state is state 1, only then we actually need to check whether the length is too short or too long (action [2]). To clarify even more, if the username is alex. , the final state will be state 2 which is not accepted state so the userName will be discarded anyway. But let's say if the userName is A. L , the final state is 1 meaning it's in the accepted state but we still need to do action [2] to validate the length. Hope this helps.

metadata.title: HW 1 Foundation Admin login or User login validations or both?

content: Sorry for all the questions, but do we implement the UserNameRecognizer and PasswordEvaluator for the Admin login as well as the User login in the Foundation Code? Or are we just validating the User logins? I'm not seeing a distinction in the instructions.

answers.content: Think about any general setup and login page. Ideally you would validate the userName and password before creating the account, right? Login does not necessarily require validation except for checking in the database if there is a match. So, navigate through the codebase and look for where you are creating a new User. You need to add the username and password validation before that action. Hope that helps and please do not hesitate to ask any questions whatsoever, there are so many TAs and UGTAs here only to help answer your questions.

Input validation should should be done when processing any input. Failure to validate input before using it is one of the most common errors that lead to criminal breaking into systems and causing harm. In the case of a subsequent login, the only thing that matters is the length and that the string of characters matche an entry that has already entered. When creating a new user playing any role, the more detailed validation is required before you create the account.

content: For Task 5, it says to allow periods, underscores and minus signs between subsequent alphanumeric characters. Since we changed the first character to have to be alphabetic, does that mean we can allow a period at username[1] ? Or will it have to go to state 1 first and then we can allow the other characters starting at username[2]? I get that alphabetic falls under alphanumeric, just the wording in the directions makes it seem like that is not what is expected.

answers.content: The way I took this to mean and implemented is that periods, underscores and minus signs can only be between subsequent characters of 0-9 and that A-Z and a-z characters are not considered alphanumeric.

Alphanumeric refers to letters and numbers and the username cannot start with a period, underscore, or minus sign because it would violate that rule of these characters only appearing between alphanumeric characters.

Most of the time, our professor would tell you to submit something for this assignment, such as a code snippet screenshot, a picture of a slide, or a picture of your iClicker activities score to show that you were in the class. If nothing were mentioned during class, the score for this assignment will be imported from your iClicker activities during class. This is to make sure that you are engaged and pay attention to the lecture. About iClicker for the first week, here is a quote from Dr. Carter's previous respond: "As stated in the in-person class, the first week's iClicker activity is to help the in-person students get iClicker working. We will not use the first or the second week's data for in-class grading. It is to provide in-class students the opportunity to practice and resolve issues. It is every in-person class student's responsibility to get iClicker working. Online students will not be using iClicker."

In-class activities, like the Team Formation activity, require you to submit things before you leave the room. In-class students are also expected to participate in iClicker polls. The combination of these two things determine you in-class participation. Week 1's activity was Team Formation submission. Week 2's activity will be evidence that you have ASUHelloWorldJavaFX running (or the error you are having). Online students do not have a fixed time every week to meet. That said, they are expected to perform similar activities as the in-person class. (Some of these activities will be modified to deal with the reality that you are not sitting next to others in the class.) There are no iClicker polls, so those are not a factor for online students. For Everyone: Prior or every Individual Homework Assignment and Team Project Assignment, we will host a Live Event to cover an practical skills and provide an opportunity to get questions answered about the assignment interactively. Ed Dicussion is good, but it can be slower than a Live Q&A discussion. These sessions will be recorded and questioned posted to Ed Discussion starting with "Live Event Question" as the first three words in the post will be covered in the Live Event, time permitting. The Live Event will be recorded and links provided in the Canvas Module corresponding to the week of the event.

metadata.title: Establishing Team Norms: A key part of team formation

content: Please use this discussion thread as a place to describe problems you have experienced work with others that you believe teams should consider when they produce the set of Team Norms as part of the first Team Project assignment submission. Here are two examples: 1. If a team member does to respond to emails and does not attend and participate in the two (or more) weekly team meetings, a member of the team will engage with the member of the instructional team (e.g., a grader) assigned to that team, explain the situation, and work to get it resolved. 2. If a team member becomes ill and is having difficulty functioning, that team member must inform the rest of the team of the situation and work to find common ground about what is expected of the ill member after recovering from the illness to be a member in good standing with the rest of the team. (The former ill student will take on extra work to help improve the team's project to make up for the time that member was unable to participate. The whole team needs to agree that the agreement is reasonable and fair to the whole team.) What are problems you have seen? Described the situation that has occurred and will likely happen again. Do not provide your recommendation for the team norm. Each team must select a list of issue that are likely or probable and come up with the expectation for the whole team should that issue become a reality for the team. If you have questions, doubts, or suggestions for improvement to the above, so we can all better benefit from the wealth of experience you all bring.
